elements.content: Four coordination polymers constructed from the flexible isomeric bis-pyridyl-bis-amide (bpba) ligands, N,N′-di­(3-pyridyl)­suberoamide (L1 ) and N,N′-di­(4-pyridyl)­suberoamide (L2 ), and the auxiliary 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2NDC), including [Co­(L1 )1.5(1,4-NDC)­(H2O)] n , 1, [Co3(L1 )1.5(1,4-NDC)3(EtOH)] n , 2, {[Co­(L2 )1.5(1,4-NDC)]­·H2O} n , 3, and {[Co­(L2 )0.5(1,4-NDC)]­·EtOH} n , 4, have been synthesized and structurally characterized by using single crystal X-ray crystallography. Complex 1 forms a two-dimensional layer with double edges and 2 exhibits a unique three-dimensional (3D) self-catenated framework with the (48.66.8)-6T60 topology, while 3 displays a 3D framework with the highest 5-fold interpenetration for the bnn topology and 4 shows a 3D 2-fold interpenetrated framework with the pcu topology. The donor atom positions of the L1 and L2 ligands and the identity of the solvents play important roles in determining the structural diversity. Moreover, irreversible structural transformation from 2 to 1 has been verified by immersing crystals of 2 into water. The coordination ability of the CH3CH2OH molecule in 2 and the thermal stability of 1 govern the irreversible structural transformation.

The donor atom positions of the L1  and L2  ligands and the identity of the solvents play important roles in determining the structural diversity. Moreover, irreversible structural transformation from 2 to 1 has been verified by immersing crystals of 2 into water. The coordination ability of the CH3CH2OH molecule in 2 and the thermal stability of 1 govern the irreversible structural transformation.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) have received much attention not only for their charming structures and distinctive topologies, but also for their numerous potential applications, such as gas storage, separation, magnetism, catalysis, and ion exchange. The structural types of CPs are susceptible to many factors, involving the nature of metal ions, linkers and counterions, ratio of metal and ligand, and coordination and cocrystallization of solvents. Therefore, it has become an important topic to employ the appropriate factors to design and construct CPs with desired properties. Although many interesting CPs have been reported, the control of structural dimensionality and entanglement is still a challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) have received much attention not only for their charming structures and distinctive topologies, but also for their numerous potential applications, such as gas storage, separation, magnetism, catalysis, and ion exchange. The structural types of CPs are susceptible to many factors, involving the nature of metal ions, linkers and counterions, ratio of metal and ligand, and coordination and cocrystallization of solvents. Therefore, it has become an important topic to employ the appropriate factors to design and construct CPs with desired properties. Although many interesting CPs have been reported, the control of structural dimensionality and entanglement is still a challenge.

elements.content: The crystal-to-crystal transformations of CPs are infrequent due to the involvement of breaking and forming of coordinate and/or covalent bonds in more than one direction, which can be initiated by various methods such as removal and uptake of solvents, exchange of solvents and guest molecules, exposure to reactive vapors and external stimuli like heat, light, and mechanical forces. Such phenomena are intriguing in CPs due to their potential applications as switches and sensors. Moreover, the structural transformations that have been reported generally have focused on the change of the initial and final structures. The factors that direct the structural change remain scarcely investigated. Entanglement is a common phenomenon in the crystal engineering of CPs, which may happen in a crystal to maximize its packing efficiency due to the presence of large free voids in a single network. Polycatenation that results in a network with higher dimension generally contains three discrete rings entangled in a way that they cannot be separated without breaking one of the rings, whereas interpenetration that retains the dimension can be ascribed to the occupation of the voids associated with one framework by one or more independent frameworks, and they can be disentangled only by breaking all the internal connections. The self-catenated nets are single nets that exhibit the peculiar feature of containing the shortest rings through which pass other components of the same network.

elements.content: The intriguing bis-pyridyl-bis-amide (bpba) ligands can be tailored to provide diverse CPs with entanglement. While several one-dimensional bpba-based CPs have been verified to show reversible or irreversible structural transformation, those that involve high dimensions are limited, and only one example showing irreversible transformation from a dinuclear metallocycle to a two-dimensional (2D) pleated grid has been reported. To investigate the effect of ligand flexibility and isomerism of bpba on the structural types of Co­(II) CPs and the impact on their properties, Co­(II) salts were reacted with the flexible isomeric ligands N,N′-di­(3-pyridyl)­suberoamide (L1 ) and N,N′-di­(4-pyridyl)­suberoamide (L2 ) and the auxiliary 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2NDC) in different solvents, affording [Co­(L1 )1.5­(1,4-NDC)­(H2O)] n (1,4-H2NDC = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid), 1, [Co3(L1 )1.5­(1,4-NDC)3­(EtOH)] n , 2, {[Co­(L2 )1.5­(1,4-NDC)]­H2O} n , 3, and {[Co­(L2 )0.5­(1,4-NDC)]­·EtOH} n , 4. While complex 1 displays a single two-dimensional (2D) layer, 2–4 show entangled structures. Moreover, complexes 1 and 2 display irreversible structural transformation upon solvent exchange. The synthesis and structural characterization of 1–4 form the subject of this report, and the factors that govern the irreversible structural transformation from 2 to 1 are also discussed.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

Elemental analyses were performed on a PE 2400 series II CHNS/O or an Elementar Vario EL cube analyzer. IR spectra (KBr disk) were obtained from a JASCO FT/IR-460 plus spectrometer. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) measurements were carried out on a TG/DTA 6200 analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were achieved by using a Bruker D2 PHASER diffractometer with CuKα (λα = 1.54 Å) radiation.

elements.content: The reagents Co­(OAc)2·H2O and 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid were purchased from Alfa Aesar. The ligands N,N′-di­(3-pyridyl)­suberoamide (L1 ) and N,N′-di­(4-pyridyl)­suberoamide (L2 ) were prepared according to published procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Materials

The reagents Co(OAc)2⋅H2O and 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid were purchased from Alfa Aesar. The ligands N,N'-di(3-pyridyl)suberoamide (L1 ) and N,N'-di(4-pyridyl)suberoamide (L2 ) were prepared according to published procedures.

elements.content: A mixture of Co­(CH3CO2)2­·2H2O (0.025 g, 0.10 mmol), L1 (0.033 g, 0.10 mmol), and 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.022 g, 0.10 mmol) in 10 mL of H2O was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave which was heated under autogenous pressure to 120 °C for 2 days. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C per hour. Pink crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were generated and collected. Yield: 0.043 g (55%). Anal. The diffraction data for complexes 1–4 were collected on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer, which was equipped with a graphite-monochromated MoKα (λα = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction was performed by standard methods with the use of well-established computational procedures. The structure factors were obtained after Lorentz and polarization corrections. An empirical absorption correction based on “multi-scan” was applied to the data for all complexes. The positions of some of the heavier atoms were located by the direct or Patterson method. The remaining atoms were found in a series of alternating difference Fourier maps and least-squares refinements, while the hydrogen atoms were added by using the HADD command in SHELXTL 6.1012. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement for 2–4 is summarized in , and that of 1 is listed in Table S1.

The remaining atoms were found in a series of alternating difference Fourier maps and least-squares refinements, while the hydrogen atoms were added by using the HADD command in SHELXTL 6.1012. Crystals of 1 conform to the monoclinic space group P1̅ with one Co­(II) ion, three halves of L1 ligand, one 1,4-NDC2– ligand, and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. a shows the coordination environment about the Co­(II) metal center, which is six-coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three L1 ligands [Co–N = 2.165(1)–2.197(1) Å], two oxygen atoms from two 1,4-NDC2– ligands [Co–O = 2.051(1)–2.079(1) Å], and one oxygen atom from the water molecule [Co–O = 2.150(1) Å]. The Co­(II) cations are linked by 1,4-NDC2– and L1 ligands to form a 2D layer with double edges, b. c depicts a simplified drawing. Topologically, if all the L1 and 1,4-NDC2– ligands are considered as linkers and each Co­(II) atom is regarded as a four-connected node, the structure of 1 can be regarded as a 4-connected net with (44.62)-sql topology, determined using ToposPro, d.

Results and Discussion

Structure of 1 

Crystals of 1 conform to the monoclinic space group P1̅ with one Co(II) ion, three halves of L1  ligand, one 1,4-NDC2- ligand, and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. a shows the coordination environment about the Co(II) metal center, which is six-coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three L1  ligands [Co-N = 2.165(1)-2.197(1) Å], two oxygen atoms from two 1,4-NDC2- ligands [Co-O = 2.051(1)-2.079(1) Å], and one oxygen atom from the water molecule [Co-O = 2.150(1) Å]. The Co(II) cations are linked by 1,4-NDC2- and L1  ligands to form a 2D layer with double edges, b. c depicts a simplified drawing. Topologically, if all the L1  and 1,4-NDC2- ligands are considered as linkers and each Co(II) atom is regarded as a four-connected node, the structure of 1 can be regarded as a 4-connected net with (44.62)-sql topology, determined using ToposPro, d.

elements.content: The 2D nets are supported by the coordinated water molecules via O–H---O hydrogen bonds (H---O = 1.98 Å, O---O = 2.77 Å, ∠O–H---O = 174°) to the amide carbonyl oxygen atoms of the L1 ligands and to the carboxylate oxygen atoms of the 1,4-NDC2– ligands (H---O = 1.87 Å, O---O = 2.74 Å, ∠O–H---O = 163°), Figure S1. The nets are also linked by the N–H---O hydrogen bonds from amine hydrogen atoms of the of the L1 ligands to the carboxylate oxygen atoms (H---O = 2.23 and 2.01 Å, N---O = 2.93 and 2.73 Å, ∠N–H---O = 139 and 141°) and to the amide oxygen atoms (H---O = 2.20 Å, N---O = 2.97 Å, ∠N–H---O = 150°).

elements.content: Crystals of 2 conforms to the monoclinic space group P21/c with three Co­(II) ions, three halves of L1 ligand, three 1,4-NDC2– ligands, and one coordinated ethanol molecule in the asymmetric unit. a shows the coordination environment about the Co­(II) metal center, showing that all the Co(1), Co(2), and Co(3) metal centers are six-coordinated. Co(1) is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two L1 ligands [Co(1)–N = 2.121(3)–2.201(3) Å] and four oxygen atoms from three 1,4-NDC2– ligands [Co(1)–O = 2.025(3)–2.201(3) Å], while Co(2) is coordinated by six oxygen atoms from six 1,4-NDC2– ligands [Co(2)–O = 2.009 (3)–2.211(3) Å] and Co(3) is coordinated by one nitrogen atom from the L1 ligand [Co(3)–N = 2.082 (3) Å], four oxygen atoms from three 1,4-NDC2– ligands [Co(3)–O = 1.993(3)–2.240(3) Å], and one oxygen atom from the ethanol molecule [Co(3)–O = 2.249(3) Å]. The Co­(II) cations are linked by the 1,4-NDC2– ligands to form trinuclear secondary building units, which are further connected by the L1 ligands to form a three-dimensional (3D) framework.

Structure of 2

Co(1) is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two L1  ligands [Co(1)-N = 2.121(3)-2.201(3) Å] and four oxygen atoms from three 1,4-NDC2- ligands [Co(1)-O = 2.025(3)-2.201(3) Å], while Co(2) is coordinated by six oxygen atoms from six 1,4-NDC2- ligands [Co(2)-O = 2.009 (3)-2.211(3) Å] and Co(3) is coordinated by one nitrogen atom from the L1  ligand [Co(3)-N = 2.082 (3) Å], four oxygen atoms from three 1,4-NDC2- ligands [Co(3)-O = 1.993(3)-2.240(3) Å], and one oxygen atom from the ethanol molecule [Co(3)-O = 2.249(3) Å]. The Co(II) cations are linked by the 1,4-NDC2- ligands to form trinuclear secondary building units, which are further connected by the L1  ligands to form a three-dimensional (3D) framework.

elements.content: If each trinuclear secondary building unit is regarded as a six-connected node, the structure of 2 can be simplified as a self-catenated net with (48.66.8)-6T60 topology, determined using ToposPro, b. Complex 2 is the first coordination network reported with such topology. Noticeably, each independent six-membered ring is catenated with the other two rings, c. The self-catenated net is supported by the N–H---O (H---O = 2.17, 2.44, and 2.12 Å, N---O = 2.95, 3.25, and 2.87 Å, ∠N–H---O = 148, 153, and 142°) hydrogen bonds from the amine hydrogen atoms of the of the L1 ligands to the carboxylate oxygen atoms of the 1,4-NDC2– ligands, Figure S2.

The self-catenated net is supported by the N-H---O (H---O = 2.17, 2.44, and 2.12 Å, N---O = 2.95, 3.25, and 2.87 Å, ∠N-H---O = 148, 153, and 142°) hydrogen bonds from the amine hydrogen atoms of the of the L1  ligands to the carboxylate oxygen atoms of the 1,4-NDC2- ligands, Figure S2.

elements.content: Crystals of 3 conform to the monoclinic space group P21/c with one Co­(II) ion, three halves of L2 ligand, one 1,4-NDC2– ligand, and one cocrystallized water molecule in the asymmetric unit. a shows the coordination environment about the Co­(II) metal center, which is six-coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three L2 ligands [Co–N = 2.107(2)–2.193(2) Å] and three oxygen atoms from two 1,4-NDC2– ligands [Co–O = 2.0059(17)–2.2514(17) Å]. The Co­(II) cations are linked by the 1,4-NDC2– and L2 ligands to form a 3D framework. Topologically, each Co­(II) atom can be regarded as a five-connected node, and the structure of 3 can be simplified as a 5-fold interpenetrated network with the (46.64)-bnn topology, determined using ToposPro, b,c. The five nets are related by a single translation [1,0,0], and belong to class Ia. According to the TTO database of ToposPro, the maximum number of interpenetration that has been reported for bnn in coordination networks is four, and there is only one example. Complex 3 thus exhibits the highest number of interpenetration presently known for bnn.

elements.content: Crystals of 4 conform to the monoclinic space group C2/c with one Co­(II) ion, one-half of L2 ligand, one 1,4-NDC2– ligand, and one cocrystallized ethanol molecule in the asymmetric unit. a shows the coordination environment about the Co­(II) metal center, which is five-coordinated by one nitrogen atom from one L2 ligand [Co–N = 2.051(3) Å] and four oxygen atoms from four 1,4-NDC2– ligands [Co–O = 2.005(2)–2.135(2) Å]. The adjacent Co­(II) ions are connected by 1,4-NDC2– ligands to give dinuclear units with the distance of Co---Co being 2.8692 Å. Furthermore, the Co­(II) anions are linked by1,4-H2NDC2– and L2 ligands to form a 3D framework. Topologically, each Co­(II) atom can be regarded as a five-connected node and the 1,4-NDC2– ligand as a four-connected node, resulting in a 2-fold interpenetrated network with the (42,62,82)­(46,64)-xah topology (standard representation), determined using ToposPro, b. If the dinuclear Co2 units are regarded as a 6-connected node, the structure of 4 can be further simplified as a 2-fold interpenetrated network with the (412,63)-pcu topology (cluster representation), c. The 2-fold interpenetrated net is supported by the N–H---O (H---O = 2.22 Å, N---O = 3.03 Å, ∠N–H---O = 152°) hydrogen bonds from the amine hydrogen atoms of the of the L2 ligands to the carboxylate oxygen atoms of the 1,4-NDC2– ligands, Figure S4.

elements.content: The long carbon chains in the middle of L1 and L2 make them quite flexible. The L1 and L2 can be arranged in A and G conformations, which are given when the C–C–C–C torsion angle (θ) is 180 ≥ θ > 90° and 0 ≤ θ ≤ 90°, respectively. On the basis of the relative orientation of the CO (or N–H) groups, each conformation can adopt cis or trans arrangement. Due to the difference in the orientations of the pyridyl nitrogen atom positions, three more orientations, anti–anti, syn–anti, and syn–syn, are possible for the ligand. The ligand conformations of complexes 1–4 are assigned accordingly and listed in . The two independent L2 ligands in 3 adopt the same AAAAA-trans conformation, although their C–C–C–C torsional angles are significant different.
elements.clean_text:
Ligand Conformations and Bonding Modes

The long carbon chains in the middle of L1  and L2  make them quite flexible. The L1  and L2  can be arranged in A and G conformations, which are given when the C-C-C-C torsion angle (θ) is 180 ≥ θ > 90° and 0 ≤ θ ≤ 90°, respectively. On the basis of the relative orientation of the CO (or N-H) groups, each conformation can adopt cis or trans arrangement. Due to the difference in the orientations of the pyridyl nitrogen atom positions, three more orientations, anti-anti, syn-anti, and syn-syn, are possible for the ligand. The ligand conformations of complexes 1-4 are assigned accordingly and listed in . The two independent L2  ligands in 3 adopt the same AAAAA-trans conformation, although their C-C-C-C torsional angles are significant different.

The 1,4-NDC2– ligands in 1–4 adopt various types of bonding modes. While the bonding mode in 1 is μ2 -κ1,κ0,κ1,κ0, a, those in 2 show three different bonding modes, which are μ4 -κ1,κ1,κ1,κ1, b, μ3 -κ1,κ1,κ1,κ1, c, and μ4 -κ2,κ1,κ1,κ1, d, respectively. The 1,4-NDC2– ligand in 3 adopts the μ2 -κ1,κ1,κ1,κ0 bonding mode, e, and that in 4 is μ4 -κ1,κ1,κ1,κ1. To show the distinctive 3D self-catenated framework with the (48.66.8) topology, the 1,4-NDC2– ligands in 2 adopt three different bonding modes, which is unique for the 1,4-NDC2– ligands in a single structure.

elements.content: Structural comparisons for complexes 1–4 reveal the important roles of solvent and ligand isomerism in the structural diversity. Different donor atom positions of L1 and L2 result in various bonding modes for the 1,4-NDC2– ligands and different coordination abilities for the H2O and EtOH molecules. While the H2O and EtOH molecules in 1 and 2 are coordinated to the Co­(II) metal centers, those in 3 and 4 are cocrystallized with the metal complexes, resulting in a 2D layer with double edges, a 3D self-catenated framework with the (48.66.8)-6T60 topology, a 3D 5-fold interpenetrated framework with bnn topology, and a 3D 2-fold interpenetrated framework with pcu topology, respectively. Other things being equal, the structural differences in the pairs of 1 and 2, and 3 and 4 are subject to the nature of the H2O and EtOH molecules, while the pairs of 1 and 3, and 2 and 4 show the effect of the ligand isomerism of L1 and L2 .
elements.clean_text:
Structural Diversity

Structural comparisons for complexes 1-4 reveal the important roles of solvent and ligand isomerism in the structural diversity. Different donor atom positions of L1  and L2  result in various bonding modes for the 1,4-NDC2- ligands and different coordination abilities for the H2O and EtOH molecules. While the H2O and EtOH molecules in 1 and 2 are coordinated to the Co(II) metal centers, those in 3 and 4 are cocrystallized with the metal complexes, resulting in a 2D layer with double edges, a 3D self-catenated framework with the (48.66.8)-6T60 topology, a 3D 5-fold interpenetrated framework with bnn topology, and a 3D 2-fold interpenetrated framework with pcu topology, respectively. Other things being equal, the structural differences in the pairs of 1 and 2, and 3 and 4 are subject to the nature of the H2O and EtOH molecules, while the pairs of 1 and 3, and 2 and 4 show the effect of the ligand isomerism of L1  and L2 .

elements.content: In order to estimate the thermal properties of the structures, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of complexes 1–4 were carried out in a nitrogen atmosphere from 30 to 1000 °C, Figures S5–S8 and . The TGA curve of 1 shows the gradual weight loss of the coordinated water molecules (calculated 2.3%, observed 2.5%) in 160–250 °C, and the weight loss of 86.3% in 300–900 °C corresponds to the decomposition of L1 and 1,4-NDC2– ligands (calculated 90.1%), while the TGA curve of 2 shows the gradual weight loss of the coordinated ethanol molecules (calculated 3.4%, observed 2.1%) in 30–204 °C, and the weight loss of 86.1% in 204–850 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of L1 and 1,4-H2NDC2– ligands (calculated 83.6%). For complex 3, the TGA curve shows the removal of the crystallized water molecules in 30–285 °C, and the weight loss of 89.8% in 285–1000 °C is due to the decomposition of L2 and 1,4-H2NDC2– ligands (calculated 90.1%). The TGA curve of 4 shows the removal of the crystallized EtOH molecules in 30–310 °C, and the host framework collapses in 310–900 °C with a weight loss of 81.9% due to the decomposition of L2 and 1,4-H2NDC2– ligands (calculated 78.2%).

Thermal Properties

In order to estimate the thermal properties of the structures, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of complexes 1-4 were carried out in a nitrogen atmosphere from 30 to 1000 °C, Figures S5-S8 and . The TGA curve of 1 shows the gradual weight loss of the coordinated water molecules (calculated 2.3%, observed 2.5%) in 160-250 °C, and the weight loss of 86.3% in 300-900 °C corresponds to the decomposition of L1  and 1,4-NDC2- ligands (calculated 90.1%), while the TGA curve of 2 shows the gradual weight loss of the coordinated ethanol molecules (calculated 3.4%, observed 2.1%) in 30-204 °C, and the weight loss of 86.1% in 204-850 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of L1  and 1,4-H2NDC2- ligands (calculated 83.6%). For complex 3, the TGA curve shows the removal of the crystallized water molecules in 30-285 °C, and the weight loss of 89.8% in 285-1000 °C is due to the decomposition of L2  and 1,4-H2NDC2- ligands (calculated 90.1%). The TGA curve of 4 shows the removal of the crystallized EtOH molecules in 30-310 °C, and the host framework collapses in 310-900 °C with a weight loss of 81.9% due to the decomposition of L2  and 1,4-H2NDC2- ligands (calculated 78.2%).

It is worthwhile to investigate the factors that govern the structural transformation in high-dimensional bpba-based CPs since entangled networks of this type have never been found to perform structural transformation. To investigate the transformation due to solvent exchange, we first checked the purities of complexes 1 and 2 by measuring their powder X-ray diffraction patterns. Figures S9 and S10 show that the powder patterns of these two complexes match quite well with those simulated from single-crystal X-ray data, indicating the bulk purities of these complexes. We then investigated the feasibility of structural transformation due to solvent exchange for these CPs. shows the irreversible structural transformation between 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text:
Irreversible Structural Transformation Due to Solvent Exchange

It is worthwhile to investigate the factors that govern the structural transformation in high-dimensional bpba-based CPs since entangled networks of this type have never been found to perform structural transformation. To investigate the transformation due to solvent exchange, we first checked the purities of complexes 1 and 2 by measuring their powder X-ray diffraction patterns. Figures S9 and S10 show that the powder patterns of these two complexes match quite well with those simulated from single-crystal X-ray data, indicating the bulk purities of these complexes. We then investigated the feasibility of structural transformation due to solvent exchange for these CPs.  shows the irreversible structural transformation between 1 and 2.

elements.content: Complex 1 was first immersed into various organic solvents at room temperature for 1 week, and it was shown that no change can be observed, as depicted in Figure S13. We then tried to remove the coordinated water molecules of complex 1 by heating it at 250 °C under a vacuum to give the dehydrated 1 (1′), Figure S14. Complex 1′ was then allowed to absorb various organic solvents at room temperature for 1 week to explore the structural change. However, the powder X-ray patterns remain unchanged, Figure S15. Even refluxing or hydrothermally reacting 1′ in EtOH could not change the powder pattern, indicating the stability of 1′, Figures S16 and S17. It is noteworthy that 1′ could only be transformed back to 1 by soaking in water for 1 week, Figure S18. Fortunately, when complex 2 was immersed in water, a vigorous reaction was observed. After standing for 1 day, the color of the complex changed from purple to pink. The solid was then collected and investigated by using PXRD patterns, , which demonstrates the irreversible crystal-to-crystal transformation due to solvent exchange. On the other hand, immersing 4 in H2O afforded a light yellow solid that displayed PXRD patterns different from those of 3 and 4, Figure S19.

elements.content: The structural transformation in supramolecular isomers that comprise network structures that have identical chemical compositions but differ from one another in their structures is feasible because no gain or loss of ligands is demanded. However, for those that are not supramolecular isomers, decomposition of the complex or rearrangement of the ligands during the process is anticipated. It is thus worthwhile to comment on the irreversible structural transformation between 1 and 2. In complex 1, the ratio of Co/L1 /1,4-NDC2– is 1:1.5:1, while that in 2 is 3:1.5:3. On the basis of the metal to ligand ratio, decomposition of 2 is thus necessary for the formation of 1, which also demonstrates the irreversibility of the structural transformation from 2 to 1. The average yield for the structural transformation is about 71% based on three experiments, Figure S20.

elements.content: shows that the removal of the coordinated CH3CH2OH molecules of 2 started from 30 °C, and the organic ligands (L1 and 1,4-NDC2–) decomposed at 204 °C, while the removal of the coordinated H2O molecules of 1 occurred in 160–250 °C and the organic ligands decomposed at 300 °C, indicating the weaker coordination of the CH3CH2OH molecules to the Co­(II) metal ions than the H2O molecules and the better stability of the framework of 1 than 2. The irreversible structural transformation from 2 to 1 can thus most probably be ascribed to the weak coordination ability of the CH3CH2OH molecules and weak framework strength of 2 due to the formation of the self-catenated net with a (48.66.8)-6T60 topology, which triggered the decomposition of the complex and rearrangement of the ligands upon immersing to water to conform to the structure of 1 that is more thermally stable.

elements.content: Four new Co­(II) CPs constructed from the flexible bpba, L1 and L2 , and 1,4-NDC2– ligands have been successfully synthesized. Complex 1 forms a 2D layer with double edges and 2 exhibits a unique 3D self-catenated framework with the (48.66.8)-6T60 topology, while 3 displays a 3D framework with the highest 5-fold interpenetration for the bnn topology and 4 shows a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework with the pcu topology. The structural diversity is directed by the ligand-isomerism of L1 and L2 as well as the identity of the solvents. Complexes 1 and 2 display irreversible structural transformation upon solvent exchange, which may demonstrate that the 3D self-catenated framework of 2 is thermally less stable than the 2D layer of 1. The weak coordination ability of CH3CH2OH molecules and the weak strength of the self-catenated framework of 2 are responsible for the initiation of the structural transformation. This study provides insight into understanding the irreversibility of the structural transformation of the entangled CPs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Four new Co(II) CPs constructed from the flexible bpba, L1  and L2 , and 1,4-NDC2- ligands have been successfully synthesized. Complex 1 forms a 2D layer with double edges and 2 exhibits a unique 3D self-catenated framework with the (48.66.8)-6T60 topology, while 3 displays a 3D framework with the highest 5-fold interpenetration for the bnn topology and 4 shows a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework with the pcu topology. The structural diversity is directed by the ligand-isomerism of L1  and L2  as well as the identity of the solvents. Complexes 1 and 2 display irreversible structural transformation upon solvent exchange, which may demonstrate that the 3D self-catenated framework of 2 is thermally less stable than the 2D layer of 1. The weak coordination ability of CH3CH2OH molecules and the weak strength of the self-catenated framework of 2 are responsible for the initiation of the structural transformation. This study provides insight into understanding the irreversibility of the structural transformation of the entangled CPs.

A mixture of Co­(CH3CO2)2­·2H2O (0.025 g, 0.10 mmol), L1 (0.033 g, 0.10 mmol), and 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.022 g, 0.10 mmol) in 10 mL of H2O was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave which was heated under autogenous pressure to 120 °C for 2 days. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C per hour. Pink crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were generated and collected. Yield: 0.043 g (55%). Anal. Calcd for C39H41CoN6O8 (MW = 780.71): C, 59.98; H, 5.29; N, 10.76%. Found: C, 59.90; H, 5.23; N, 10.74%. cln_elements.content: In order to estimate the thermal properties of the structures, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of complexes 1–4 were carried out in a nitrogen atmosphere from 30 to 1000 °C, Figures S5–S8 and . The TGA curve of 1 shows the gradual weight loss of the coordinated water molecules (calculated 2.3%, observed 2.5%) in 160–250 °C, and the weight loss of 86.3% in 300–900 °C corresponds to the decomposition of L1 and 1,4-NDC2– ligands (calculated 90.1%), while the TGA curve of 2 shows the gradual weight loss of the coordinated ethanol molecules (calculated 3.4%, observed 2.1%) in 30–204 °C, and the weight loss of 86.1% in 204–850 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of L1 and 1,4-H2NDC2– ligands (calculated 83.6%). For complex 3, the TGA curve shows the removal of the crystallized water molecules in 30–285 °C, and the weight loss of 89.8% in 285–1000 °C is due to the decomposition of L2 and 1,4-H2NDC2– ligands (calculated 90.1%). The TGA curve of 4 shows the removal of the crystallized EtOH molecules in 30–310 °C, and the host framework collapses in 310–900 °C with a weight loss of 81.9% due to the decomposition of L2 and 1,4-H2NDC2– ligands (calculated 78.2%).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Properties

In order to estimate the thermal properties of the structures, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of complexes 1-4 were carried out in a nitrogen atmosphere from 30 to 1000 °C, Figures S5-S8 and . The TGA curve of 1 shows the gradual weight loss of the coordinated water molecules (calculated 2.3%, observed 2.5%) in 160-250 °C, and the weight loss of 86.3% in 300-900 °C corresponds to the decomposition of L1  and 1,4-NDC2- ligands (calculated 90.1%), while the TGA curve of 2 shows the gradual weight loss of the coordinated ethanol molecules (calculated 3.4%, observed 2.1%) in 30-204 °C, and the weight loss of 86.1% in 204-850 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of L1  and 1,4-H2NDC2- ligands (calculated 83.6%). For complex 3, the TGA curve shows the removal of the crystallized water molecules in 30-285 °C, and the weight loss of 89.8% in 285-1000 °C is due to the decomposition of L2  and 1,4-H2NDC2- ligands (calculated 90.1%). The TGA curve of 4 shows the removal of the crystallized EtOH molecules in 30-310 °C, and the host framework collapses in 310-900 °C with a weight loss of 81.9% due to the decomposition of L2  and 1,4-H2NDC2- ligands (calculated 78.2%).
